primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God intervenes in the human condition of universal sin and self-deception to justify the ungodly through the substitutionary death of Christ.

subject.identificatie: God (specifically in the person of Jesus Christ)
tekstueel_bewijs: God has shown us a great thing.
Jesus, the Son of God, has voluntarily taken our place.
He has wrought the salvation of his enemies.
salvation of each and every one of us

zender.identificatie: God the Father / The Holiness of God
tekstueel_bewijs: the reality of God, the power of God, the holiness of God

helper.identificatie: Jesus Christ (as Mediator) and the Holy Spirit
tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus... bearing in his own body the storm of the wrath

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin as a Cosmic Power / Self-Deception / The Wrath of God
tekstueel_bewijs: the storm of the wrath of God against sin
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is treated not just as a mistake but as a condition requiring a divine death to nullify.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The believer responds to God's grace through honest confession and the cessation of judging others.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer/Believer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The knowledge of grace precedes and enables the confession of sin.

voorbeelden_god_subject: God has shown us a great thing.
He has wrought the salvation of his enemies.
God sees you as you really are.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We throw ourselves on his mercy.
We do not need to lie to ourselves.

voorbeelden: action has to be taken against evil deeds
Our temptation will be... to try to squirm off the hook
The knowledge of grace has preceded the confession of sin.
God is truly able to do away with sin.
let each one find thee mighty to save.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes God's 'ability' (Pouvoir) over the human 'obligation' (Devoir). Human inability is the starting point for Divine power.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from S2 (Judgment) to ~S2 (Self-Justification) to S1 (Grace) via Christ taking S2.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Christ bears the 'storm of wrath' (S2) so the sinner can move from pretense (~S1) to righteousness (S1).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Very high; sin is described as an offense against a holy God that requires a sacrifice.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon consistently places God as the primary actor in the work of salvation. Human action (repentance) is framed as a 'response to' rather than a 'condition for' grace.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: The psalmist demonstrated that he has learned to see sin as God sees it.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: There is Another who has taken the sentence upon himself.
The knowledge of grace has preceded the confession of sin.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: The Psalmist is used as a model of self-knowledge, but this is immediately grounded in God's prior mercy.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: God is the one who grants the Psalmist the insight to see sin truly.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the 'exhausting charade' of self-justification.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'Heavy Opponent' (Sin/Wrath) to the 'Divine Subject' (Christ) is seamless.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'sinned against God only' and the reality of hurting neighbors.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus, the Son of God, has voluntarily taken our place.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit is asked to 'Create and make in us new and contrite hearts'.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is an 'onslaught' and a 'storm' directed against God.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon is a robustly theocentric narrative where God is the Subject of the rescue and man is the Receiver of a gift he cannot produce.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain current balance; it serves the Lenten theme of human helplessness.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a textbook example of grace-oriented homiletics. It avoids the trap of making repentance a 'work' by framing it as a gift of insight granted by the Savior.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While rhetoric might focus on the use of Tolkien/Solzhenitsyn as 'hooks', semiotics reveals they serve to define the 'Opponent' as universal and internal.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains Psalm 51; semiotics shows that the sermon's 'engine' is the Subject-switch from the Psalmist's effort to Christ's substitution.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas' model exposes that even when the preacher says 'We must repent,' the underlying structure shows God as the one who provides the 'Pouvoir' (power) and 'Savoir' (insight) to do so.

appendices.notities: The sermon successfully navigates the 'Subject-Check' by ensuring God is the agent of the most critical verbs (save, justify, love, die).
